title.narrative: Assessment of the potential for a Water Retention Strategy for key areas in the Mekong Delta

description.narrative: What are the results of the project?The “deep lying” upper Mekong Delta (MD) is characterized by annual river flooding and occasional extreme flooding. It is made up of the Plain of Reeds (PoR) in Long An and Dong Thap, and the Long Xuyen Quadrangle (LXQ) in An Giang and Kien Giang provinces. These areas have experienced significant dike building for expansion of a third annual rice crop and to protect homesteads and human settlements from flooding, which has reduced flood water retention capacity and enhanced extreme floods in 2011. This also causes a decrease in rice yields due to soil degradation and a lack of sedimentation.Many agree that the trend of reducing water retention potential must be reversed in the context of effects of climate change and sea level rise, upstream developments such as dam building, and unsustainable practices such as groundwater extraction (that causes land subsidence), and sand mining in river beds (that causes river bank and coastal erosion). But not all stakeholders fully agree, and how to increase water retention is not entirely clear.There have been proposals to formulate a Water Retention Strategy (WRS) for the PoR and LXQ, or a sub-strategy that would be part of a larger Mekong Delta Master Planning. This should facilitate controlled river flooding and natural sediment disposure in the wet season; reduce salinity intrusion in the middle delta and function as a buffer of fresh water against drought; counteract land subsidence and increase soil fertility and biodiversity; and flood-based livelihoods would allow farmers to escape the poverty trap of rice production.The large-scale transformation of the water retention capacity of the PoR and LXQ would be consistent with long-term visions such as a “safe, prosperous and sustainable” Mekong Delta by 2100, according to the “agro-business industrialization” scenario in the Mekong Delta Plan (MDP). This assignment focused on questions and knowledge gaps related to increased water retention potential in the PoR and LXQ. It addresses water retention history and potential, the rationale for a water retention strategy, livelihood adaptation, agricultural practices and the integrated retention potential.
